title.narrative: Grupo de Monitoreo Independiente de el Salvador

description.narrative:
UUSC is investigating the implementation of the U.S. State Department's CAM in-country processing program to determine whether at-risk minors in Central America are able to access the program, whether they receive adequate protection during the application process, and whether knowledge of the program is accessible to eligible minors at risk and their families in the U.S. This project seeks to provide the first systematic documentation of protection concerns that have been highlighted anecdotally by advocates in the field. These concerns include the potential danger that children who are in hiding or facing threats may be putting themselves in added jeopardy by traveling to public CAM application centers; the concern that children are being trapped in dangerous situations in their countries of origin for inordinate periods of time by the lengthy application process and by the threat of losing CAM applicant status if they are forced to flee the country; and more.
GMIES will provide data from El Salvador to support this research, through conducting interviews with families of CAM beneficiaries, CAM-eligible minors who were unable to access the program, minors who are interested in seeking asylum in the United States but are not eligible for CAM, and organizations and independent researchers knowledgeable about CAM.
